unnormalised: **Quora Post: Yoga Practices in Lifestyle & Wellness**
normalised: **Quora Post: Yoga Practices in Lifestyle and Wellness**

unnormalised: Okay, so I've been dabbling in yoga for about 5 years now, and let me tell you, it's been quite the journey from barely touching my toes to actually enjoying a headstand (with wall support, of course!). It all started after I watched "Dil Dhadakne Do" – remember that scene where Shefali Shah is doing yoga to de-stress? I thought, "If it can calm Mrs. Mehra down, maybe it can help me too!"
normalised: Okay, so I've been dabbling in yoga for about five years now, and let me tell you, it's been quite the journey from barely touching my toes to actually enjoying a headstand (with wall support, of course!). It all started after I watched "Dil Dhadakne Do" – remember that scene where Shefali Shah is doing yoga to de-stress? I thought, "If it can calm Missus Mehra down, maybe it can help me too!"

unnormalised: Initially, I tried following online videos, but quickly realized I needed proper guidance. That’s when I enrolled in classes at the local branch of the Morarji Desai National Institute of Yoga near Connaught Place, Delhi. It was a game changer!
normalised: Initially, I tried following online videos, but quickly realized I needed proper guidance. That’s when I enrolled in classes at the local branch of the Morarji Desai National Institute of Yoga near Connaught Place, Delhi. It was a game changer!

unnormalised: They focus on the traditional aspects, not just the Instagram-friendly poses. Learning proper breathing techniques (Pranayama) was surprisingly impactful. I used to get terrible tension headaches, and now I can usually ward them off with just a few minutes of Anulom Vilom.
normalised: They focus on the traditional aspects, not just the Instagram-friendly poses. Learning proper breathing techniques (Pranayama) was surprisingly impactful. I used to get terrible tension headaches, and now I can usually ward them off with just a few minutes of Anulom Vilom.

unnormalised: Beyond the physical benefits, like increased flexibility and a stronger core, I've noticed a definite improvement in my mental wellbeing. It's like a mini-meditation session that helps me center myself before the chaos of the day begins. My schedule includes Surya Namaskar (Sun Salutations) thrice a week. Though a bit much, it has helped me feel much more positive throughout the day. I still can't do a perfect Shirshasana unassisted, but I'm definitely progressing. Baby steps, right? And yes, sometimes I still feel like Mrs. Mehra, but at least now I have a healthier way to deal with it than chain-smoking!
